titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Adee Dodge Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 07:15

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Adee Dodge Papers consist of drawings, research files, financial records, correspondence, and biographical files documenting the life and work of Navajo visual artist and linguist Adee Dodge. Personal papers consist chiefly of biographical documentation compiled by Dodge's daughter, Nanabah Grogan. Business papers document Dodge's uranium prospecting business in the 1950s. Research files document Dodge's research on the Navajo language and on the comparative mythology of peoples of the Native Southwest and other world cultures, including Europe and India. Also included is a transcript of the autobiography of Alex Charging Crow (also known as Alex Adams) in Lakota and in English. The custodial history of this autobiography, and Dodge's relationship to it, are undetermined. Artwork consists chiefly of sketches by Dodge, some of which are drafts of paintings. Photographs document Dodge's life and family, the landscape and people of the Navajo Nation, and Dodge's paintings. Other material includes realia (two wool rugs and art supplies).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Silver Wolf Books on the Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana, 2005.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 5 (audio cassettes): Access to original audio tapes is restricted. Reference copy may be requested. Contact Access Services for further information.
Box 63 (acetate audiodisc): Restricted fragile material. Reference copy may be requested. Contact Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Adee Dodge Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Adee Dodge Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Former call numbers: Uncat MSS 762, Uncat MSS 781
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and in some instances minimal organization in 2012.

As a rule, descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Personal Papers and Business Papers, 1935-2005. II. Artwork, circa 1950-1973. III. Research Files, 1930-circa 1999. IV. Photographs, circa 1930-1992. V. Realia, undated.

bioghist.head: Adee Dodge (1912-1992)
bioghist.p: Adee Dodge, Navajo artist and linguist, was born Adolph Dodge Bitanny on November 16, 1912 in Fort Defiance, Arizona and died January 4, 1992 in Santa Fe, New Mexico. He served in the National Guard and the Army Air Corps from 1931 to 1947, achieving the rank of Captain. He studied Navajo orthography and linguistics at the Hogan School in 1934, under the guidance of Gladys Reichard. He briefly studied Anthropology at Columbia University, where he collaborated with Reichard as a linguistic consultant. In the 1930s and 1940s he worked chiefly as a Navajo language teacher and translator and contributed to a Navajo medical dictionary. In the 1950s he forayed into uranium mining, founding Adee Dodge Enterprises, Inc. His prolific career as a visual artist, begun circa 1945, flourished in his later years, when he met with commercial success.
Dodge married Effie Jean Casey in 1943, and married Veah (Mauscha M.) Pillsbury in 1950. He had one daughter, Nanabah Grogan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Adee Dodge Papers consist of drawings, research files, financial records, correspondence, and biographical files documenting the life and work of Navajo visual artist and linguist Adee Dodge. Personal papers consist chiefly of biographical documentation compiled by Dodge's daughter, Nanabah Grogan. Business papers document Dodge's uranium prospecting business in the 1950s. Research files document Dodge's research on the Navajo language and on the comparative mythology of peoples of the Native Southwest and other world cultures, including Europe and India. Also included is a transcript of the autobiography of Alex Charging Crow (also known as Alex Adams) in Lakota and in English. The custodial history of this autobiography, and Dodge's relationship to it, are undetermined. Artwork consists chiefly of sketches, some of which are drafts of paintings. Photographs document Dodge's life and family, the landscape and people of the Navajo Nation, and Dodge's paintings. Other material includes realia (two wool rugs and art supplies).

arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I consists of biographical files, correspondence, and legal and financial documents. Personal papers consist chiefly of biographical documentation compiled by Dodge's daughter, Nanabah Grogan. Business papers document Dodge's uranium prospecting business in the 1950s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes articles of incorporation, clippings, maps, and material related to uranium prospecting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes biographical notes by Dodge's daughter, personal documents, correspondence, and ephemera.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Papers Relating to Artwork, Drawings and Sketches, and Other Artwork.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II consists chiefly of sketches by Adee Dodge and records relating to the sale of his artwork. Also included are several paintings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III consists of correspondence, notes, and clippings relating to Dodge's research on Navajo language, history, and ethnography, and on comparative Native American, European, and Asian mythology. Also included is a transcript (in Lakota) of the autobiography of Alex Charging Crow (also known as Alex Adams), and an English translation.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five subseries: Adee Dodge and Family, Adee Dodge Paintings, Events, Landscape, and Other Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV consists of photographs of Adee Dodge and family, of Dodge's paintings, and of the people and landscape of the Navajo Nation.

arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.
